segments.text: You were telling me about working and going to school and how you, how you, you know, can do something for yourself if you really take the opportunity.
That was going to give you something.
Oh, yeah, but, yes.
The trouble has been also in the educational circles of the Anglo-American that

the writers of history have not written the truth have slanted the historical events to their own liking and even their school taxes texts and books they have had misinformation particularly by some individual who was
not at all adequately prepared to write in the textbooks for the state of Texas.
I remember distinctly, I think it was in the fifth grade, and I was in, I think in Bailey School, in which the teacher got me to stand up to read a joke from the geography
textbook furnished by the school system in the discussion of Texas.
It says, Texas has great centers of education and industry.
To wit, Dallas, Houston, San Antonio,
in El Paso.
But El Paso, San Antonio is troubled because of the racial condition.
The population, a great part of the population of San Antonio and El Paso are
Mexicans, and they are ignorant and illiterate.
The teacher said, Frank, you don't want to be ignorant, and you don't want to be illiterate, do you, Frank?
I said, no, and I think this book is a big liar.
And I threw it down.
I was in Bailey School.
When I was probably in the fifth grade, the teacher, Mrs. Lapp, asked me to stand up and read out to the class.
What did she say when you threw it down?
She said I was a bad boy.
How much of the problem has been in the school teachers, do you think?
Were they
Did they just not know anything, or were they unaware of the background?
Some of those crude teachers were within the category that I have mentioned before, carpetbaggers and scalawags.
This is when you say the trouble really began.
You don't think there was that much problem between the Anglos and the people who had come, well, who were there to begin with from Mexico prior to the Civil War?
I don't think there was.
I think the Civil War was a factor by the migration of the citizens from the north or unethical citizens that wanted to usurp the areas or wanted to not only usurp but wanted to

take advantage of the situation and enrich themselves probably through economic means gradually started developing a inferior type of class of citizens than they themselves because they were the conquering type we had been subjugated to their whims and desires
Now, I think that continued to go on.
And, of course, the descendants of these people took it for granted that the philosophies of the individuals before their ancestors was right.
And that there was a class distinction in Texas and El Paso
When I was going to the university, I would come to El Paso for the summer vacations, and I got me a job as a traveling salesman with a local clothing store.
And I made a trip from El Paso to Alpine.
From Alpine, I went, I think, to a little to the north, Odessa, ranking.
And what was the name of that large city in comparison to the other little towns?
What was the name of that city?
Anyway, I went to a hotel.
And I registered.
And the individual at this hotel told me that because of the Cattlemen's Convention, there was no room available.
So I inquired as to what to do.
Finally, he suggested that I should go to a Protestant
preacher's home, but he had a room available for me.
So I went to this Protestant, I don't know whether he was a Methodist preacher or a Baptist.
And they were waiting for me, and they gave me shelter and made me feel at home.
Then
Later, I went downtown.
I was peddling as a drummer, clothing, men's clothing.
And finally it dawned on me later on that the reason I didn't get a hotel room was because of racial discrimination.
Well, how did they identify you as being Mexican American?
I don't know, I guess, the manner in which I was dressed, prepared.
I found probably that I was a peddler and looking for the Mexican customers.
And we were in the business of selling exclusively to the young Mexican individuals.
And what were they doing in that particular area around Odessa?
What was their livelihood, these customers?
Employees, working people.
What's the name of that city?
San Angelo?
No.
It's between north of Vegas.
And I mean north of Alpine, between Pecos and Alpine.
I can't even think of a city in that area.
I'll look on the map.
Cattle, cattle country.
Anyway, all along,
That line from Odessa, not Odessa, Pecos, not Pecos either.
But there are two different fields of travel.
The southern and the center route.
Not Odessa, but Ranking, whatever the other, Ranking, Texas, another town.
All along that area, the oiled country, in one of the railroad stations, they had a sign.
Negro and Mexican don't let the sun set on your head here.
That was in 1928, 30, 19...
And by 1933, I saw that.
Now, in Pecos, also, there's a lot of racial discrimination.
Outspoken racial discrimination.
And it was so much worse at the early days, or right before the World War II.
Well, I'm wondering how much of this do you suppose was related to the very large number of people who did come in from Mexico?
From 1910 on up through the early 1940s, was there a fear or a feeling of being threatened by the large number of immigrants?
Or do you think this was immaterial?
I think that was immaterial about what they felt.
Here's the reason of the influx or increase of the Mexican population in the United States.
We had, during World War I, scarcity of employees.
And the same thing took place in World War II.
The United States had to import railroad trackmen, and they used to call them the ring duchies, through El Paso.

to the eastern part and central part of the united states as far as chicago now chicago has a big mexican colony because during the two wars the united states was in dire need of labor class of people and they imported these labors from mexico and the labors that were imported in the
into the United States during those areas or eras were people of low educational attainments.
They were very distinguishable in their appearance from the rest of the inhabitants of the United States.
They were very easy identifiable by the manner in which they dressed and where they lived

And consequently, that phase of our history gave rise to the superiority or a feeling of superiority by those Anglo-Americans who had been in the United States and saw these coolies, these track laborers,
uneducated bunch of people swarming into the cities of the United States.
Consequently, that appearance gave these people a brand of inferior people, of ignorant, of laborers, of that which was part of a second class of our society.
But then this has been applied or was applied generally to anyone who was of Mexican descent, regardless of?
I would think so.
The majority of that feeling came about into existence by those conditions.

So you really have the two factors then, the post-Civil War reaction, the attempt to subjugate people, and then added to that the large number of laborers who then, as a group, everyone was identified with that particular group.
In the employment of these laboring groups from Mexico, they were segregated into a particular area.
And they were given homes or places in which to live or bunk houses of an inferior quality.
And consequently, the other people who would see that would take it for granted that they were slaves, they were under class of a type of an underclass of people.
Well, it's beginning to get late, but I would like to finish just getting my record down here on your particular family.
You say your mother's family all stayed in Mexico, the Matas.
The Matas family all remained in Mexico.
Do you ever visit back and forth with these cousins?
Some of these Matas have migrated into the United States.
Did they come here?
After, yes.
After the end of the revolution.
Were they pretty well wiped out financially by the revolution?
Oh, yes.
The majority of his other relatives, when they came to the United States, they had
very, very small, if I would say economically, broke.
And then, were there any other children on your father's side, or was it just Guadalupe Galvan?
Guadalupe and Blas, B-L-A-S Galvan, and they had a, he was, he entered the United States
Sometime after we came here and went to New Mexico, married, and died in New Mexico.
Not any issue.
Did he come?
He came during the revolution, though.
Yes, he came during the revolution.
And then in your family, the children were, let's see, the oldest was?
Helen.
Ellen.
And she married... D.R.
Patton.
And they had three... Three children.
Three children who were... Hazel.
Hazel.
Um... Hmm?
I just gave you her name.
I know, I've got it on the tape.
There's another girl, and... And George.
George.
And then, let's see, the next oldest child was... Josephine.
Josephine.
And...
Did she marry?
Yes, she married a Frenchman by the name of Duplanques in her later years.
No children.
No children.
She became a furrier here in El Paso.
She has a galvan fur shop from which she retired about four years ago.
Economically, very well to do.
And then the next child was?
Oscar.
He married and had two children.
Oscar Jr., who's a lawyer.
Where does Oscar Jr. live?
Here in El Paso.
And he's married?
Married.
And Alfred Lee, who's a Catholic priest.
What did Oscar do?
Lawyer.
He's a lawyer in the United States government.
And then after Oscar was?
Raymond.
Raymond.
He's the one that went to California and worked himself to a very executive position with a telephone company.
And his children?
No children.
No children.
Married, but no children.
And the next child was?
Frank.
Got you.
And your wife's from Brazil.
And do you have any children?
No children.
We raised Oscar and Albert Lee.
I mean, helped him financially.
OK. Then this is Frank then.
Robert, the judge.
He's married and has two children.
You raised Oscar and Albert.
Yeah.
You see, Oscar passed away.
Oh, I see.
He died young.
He died.
They became orphans.
Mm-hmm.
His wife died, too.
No, his wife is alive.
Oh, but you helped raise him.
Okay, then Robert is a lawyer.
Judge of the county court at law number one.
And he married?
Emma, and they have two children.
And their children, what are their children?
Robert Jr. and Victoria.
And Robert is a, what does Robert do?
Robert Jr. Students.
They're students.
And the next child was?
Henry.
Henry.
Now after this, these were all born in the United States.
Right.
Henry.
No, Henry, pardon me.
We got Robert here.
Who's this?
That's Robert.
Yeah, well, Henry should be before Robert.
Okay.
And Henry?
Henry married, worked as a laborer at what's the name of that packing company?
He passed away
about two years ago.
Did he have any children?
He had Oscar, another Oscar, Carlos, Lawrence, Martha.
They're all students.
They're all students.
Are they high school?
University levels.
All university students.
Except one, the little girl Martha, she's going to high school.
What does his wife do?
She's a widow.
He died.
How is she affording to send these children through university?
I see.
And then...
Were there any other children?
Julie.
Julie?
Julia May.
She was born here in the States.
She got married, divorced.
She's a school teacher.
She went to Denton School for Girls.
And she's teaching here in El Paso.
Right.
And of course, after that, we had...
Lawrence, did I say Lawrence?
He passed away when he was a kid going to school.
I guess that's all.
I like to, we've talked about these people and by writing them down I can remember who it was.
Well, I'm going to have to meet my husband in a little while.
He'll wonder where I am.
